sect1.title: Shek-Pvar
sect1.para: Harn is far from being Magic Weak. Although uncommon, accomplished magi with awesome powers do exist. Characters with the interest and natural ability to practice the hidden arts have the option to enter an elite vocation that demands skill and dedication to prosper.

sect2.title: Origins of the Shek-Pvar
sect2.para: The Guild of Arcane Lore is a loose association of alchemists, astrologers, magi, rune masters etc. The Shek-Pvar is a sub-organisation (actually, six separate organisations) within the guild. Shek-Pvar subscribe to a doctrine called Pvarism. This doctrine perceives and describes Kelestia (everything that exists) in terms of six key elemental principles: Air, Fire, Metal, Earth, Water and Spirit. Because manipulation of these elements imposed unique demands upon the mind and body, six schools of arcane lore evolved, each stressing one of the elements.

sect1.title: Convocations
sect1.para: A Shek-Pvar first attunes to a Primary convocation and learns primary spells. Adjacent to this are the secondary convocations and spells. Those two removed are tertiary. The convocation opposite the primary is the diametric. These relationships are symbolised by the Pvaric Wheel.

row.entry: Counter magic, inter-world travel, energy storage

sect1.para: There is a seventh 'element', which is neutrality. Neutrality is represented by the colour grey, and corresponds to counter magic, inter world travel and energy storage.

sect1.title: Spells
sect1.para: Knowledge of convocations is merely theoretical. In order to apply that knowledge and actually cast a spell, the Shek-Pvar must have knowledge of the spell in question.

It is not possible for a Shek-Pvar to cause a magical effect without having learned a spell to perform that effect. Spontaneous magical effects are not possible according to currently understood theories of Pvarism.
A Shek-Pvar has a skill with each spell. Learning spells is actually quite easy, and it is possible to rapidly achieve a useful skill level with a spell.

sect2.title: Casting Spells
sect2.para: In order to cast a spell, the Shek-Pvar multiplies together their convocation skill and their spell skill. In effect, the convocation is treated as the attribute, and the spell is the skill. If this total matches the level of spell, then the spell is successfully cast.

sect3.title: Fatigue
sect3.para: Casting a spell can result in fatigue, the amount depending on how well the spell was cast, and the relationship of the spell's convocation to that of the Shek-Pvar.

A spell in a Shek-Pvar's primary convocation can be cast without fatigue if the casting roll is five or more points above the level of the spell. Any roll less than this causes one point of long term fatigue, regardless of whether the spell was cast or not. A diametric spell will always cause at least one level of fatigue. Neutral spells are considered to be equal to secondary spells for the purposes of fatigue.

See the table above for the full list of effects. Any failure to cast a spell results in the maximum amount of fatigue for that type of spell (so a failure to cast a tertiary or diametric spell causes four levels of fatigue to be lost).
A spell casting which results in unconsciousness is still a success, though if the spell requires concentration, then concentration is immediately lost.

sect3.title: Casting Options
sect3.para: A spell, when cast, generally requires some form of verbalisation and gesturing. Normally this consists of half a dozen to a dozen words, and the waving of an arm or arms, often denoting the target or area to be affected.
The spell must be spoken in a firm voice, so casting is rarely subtle. However, in the midst of a loud combat, or marketplace, it may be drowned out by other noises.

sect4.title: Subtle Casting
sect4.para: If desired, the Shek-Pvar can try to cast the spell more subtly. Doing so gives a casting penalty of -5 per rank of the spell. However, verbal component is reduced to a quiet voice, and arm movements are minimised. Such will still be obvious to someone watching (or talking to) the Shek-Pvar, but it will be harder for others to spot.

sect4.title: Bold and Booming
sect4.para: Conversely, a spell can be made eaier to cast by shouting the words of the spell, and using exaggerated gestures. This gives a +5 to the casting roll per rank of the spell.

sect4.title: Slow and Sure
sect4.para: Another way to improve the chance of casting a spell is to carefully prepare it. Doing so takes three times longer than normal, as well as being bold and booming.

The bonus in this case is +10 per rank of the spell being cast. The spell also requires that a magic circle is enscribed on the floor around the caster. This takes one round per rank of the highest spell being cast. This only needs to be done once however, and as many spells as desired can be cast from within the circle as long as they are all of the same convocation. Each convocation beyond the first adds an extra round to the time taken to scribe the circle.

sect4.title: Fast Casting
sect4.para: Fast casting a spell is very subtle, and has the added benefit of taking much shorter time. The spell has no verbal or gesture requirements, plus, it may be combined with other actions, even talking or fighting.

Only spells with a duration of 1 round can be fast cast. The spell occurs on the caster's initiative, then following that any other action can be performed, including casting another spell. However, a second spell cannot be fast cast, though suffers the same fast cast penalty as the original spell.
Fast casting a rank 5 spell gives a -50 penalty to the fast cast spell, and to the second spell, even if the second spell was a different rank.
Fast casting cannot be combined with other spell casting options, except for Life boosting.

sect4.title: Life boosting
sect4.para: A spell can be boosted by spending one or more fatigue levels. Each fatigue level gives a free boost to the spell, without raising the difficulty of the spell. Fatigue levels used are considered short term.

sect3.title: Spell Descriptions
sect3.para: The spells are listed with three main game attributes - level, range and resist. The level of the spell is a measure of how difficult it is to cast. Higher level spells are more powerful however.

sect4.title: Spell Level
sect4.para: The level of a spell is a measure of how complicated it is to cast. Spells have seven different complexity ranks, and each rank has a different level associated with it. Many spells can also be boosted beyond their basic level. If the spell is cast at this level (and the level is chosen before the spell is attempted), then extra effects come into play.

A level 30 spell requires a difficulty 30 spell casting roll to cast it. If it is boosted once, it becomes difficulty 30 + 15 = 45. Boosting it twice makes it level 60, and three times makes it level 90.
Ranks above X are possible, though they are extremely rare. Each subsequent rank is 50 levels higher.

sect5.title: Multi-level Spells
sect5.para: Some spells are multi-level. Only one spell needs to be learned in order to use it at all levels. The level it is cast at is determined each time just before the spell is cast. A lot of neutral spells are multi-level, as are spells to summon and control elementals.

sect4.title: Common Pvaric Spells
sect4.para: Some spells are common across all the Pvaric convocations. Once learnt, these spells can be cast as any convocation, using the relevant convocation score.

So, a young Shek-Pvar could learn Summon Elemental when she only knows the Neutral and Peleahn convocations. If summoning a Fire Elemental, she would use her Peleahn convocation. If summoning a Grey Elemental, she would use her Neutral convocation.

If the Shek-Pvar were to starting learning Jmorvi, she could immediately use her Summon Elemental spell at its full skill to summon an Iron Elemental, using her (probably very low) Jmorvi convocation.

sect4.title: Casting Time
sect4.para: Most spells can be cast in a single round. If a casting time is not given for a spell, then assume it can be cast in one round. Such spells occur during the normal initiative phase within combat. The Shek-Pvar uses agility x spell skill, with a penalty of -5 per spell rank for their initiative total.
Spells which take more than a round to cast always go off at the end of the round they are cast in. Normally such spells aren't used in combat situations anyway, so it is rarely of much importance.

sect5.title: Distractions during Spell Casting
sect5.para: If the Shek-Pvar is distracted while casting a spell, then a will roll may be needed in order to maintain concentration. If damage is sustained, a will check of difficulty 10 + 5 x body levels is required. If successful, spell casting may proceed at -5 per wound.
If the Shek-Pvar is knocked from their feet, a difficulty 30 will check is needed, which allows spell casting to continue at a -15 penalty.

If the spell takes a minute or more to cast, then distractions are less of a problem. Exact penalties are left to the GM's discretion, but basically, an 8 hour spell will not suffer from missing the odd few minutes.

sect4.title: Range
sect4.para: Spell range gives the maximum distance between caster and target. Spell ranges are divided into a few categories, which are described below. Unless otherwise stated in the spell description, there must be a line of sight between the caster and her target.

termlist.entry: The spell only affects the caster.
The spell can affect a single touched target.
The spell can affect a target very close to the caster, generally out to about three metres.
Spells with a range of eye require substantial eye contact with the target. A range of up to about ten metres is normally the practical maximum. Such spells can also affect by touch.
A target out to a range of about fifteen metres can be affected by a near spell.
Any spell with a range of short can affect targets out to a range of about fifty metres.
Medium range spells have a range of 100m.
This is the maximum range for most spells, and goes out to two hundred metres. Spells which have a longer range than this (generally detection type spells) have the specific range given.

sect4.title: Duration
sect4.para: The duration of a spell is how long it lasts after it has been cast. Most spells are either momentary, or concentration

termlist.entry: Momentary spells end as soon as they are cast. They perform some action (create a flame, change a mind), then the magic ends. The results of the magic can live on though.

Any spell with this duration lasts as long as the caster continues to concentrate on it. Concentrating on a single spell does not preclude other actions - including casting other spells. It is even possible to concentrate on more than one spell at once, though it does get progressively harder.
The first spell gives a -5 penalty to all actions (physical, perceptive and mental) while it is being concentrated on. The second spell gives a further -10 penalty, the third a -15 penalty and so on. All penalties are cumulative. Concentrating on three spells gives a total -30 penalty.
If the character suffers body levels of damage when concentrating on spells, a will check of difficulty 5 per body level is needed (remember the penalty for concentrating on spells). Failure means that half (round up) the spells are dropped. The Shek-Pvar chooses which spells to drop.

A spell with a duration of Sleep has a momentary magical duration, though the effects last until the target next sleeps. It is most common with mind affecting spells.
If the spell is one that affects the target while she sleeps, then the spell ends upon waking (and the magic remains until then as well, so can be dispelled). Four hours of sleep is enough to end the effects of the spell.

Spells with a duration of ward go dormant when they are cast. They can be detected and dispelled while dormant, though will rarely have a visible presence. When a trigger condition is met (this varies from spell to spell), the spell is activated, and its powers come into effect. The actual powers of the spell generally have a duration of momentary, so once the ward has been activated, it terminates.
Only one ward can be placed on an object, location or person at any one time. If a second ward is placed, then it automatically fails. A second ward cannot be placed within an aura of a living creature. It is not possible for a person to carry two items which are both warded. One of the wards (choose randomly) fails if this happens.
There are exceptions however. Some wards can be stacked with themselves. These are rare, and stacking always has other side effects.

sect2.title: Learning Convocations
sect2.para: When a Shek-Pvar is first trained, they are trained in a single convocation. They are attuned to this convocation for the rest of their life, and with the exception of becoming a Grey Mage, they cannot change this.

Later, it may be possible to learn a different convocation. Secondary convocations must be learned before a corresponding Tertiary convocation. 'Learned' in this case means up to a level of at least four. The diametrically opposed convocation can only be learned if both tertiary convocations are already known to a level of four.

It takes about a month to learn the basics of a new convocation, and there are political matters than need attending to as well. All this is described under the original Harn Magic rules. A Satia-Mavari (journeyman) will know their primary convocation and the neutral convocation when they enter play.

sect2.title: Learning Spells
sect2.para: Spells can either be learned or invented. Learning can be from a book, or from a tutor. Inventing spells is a long and difficult process that can take many months, or even years, so most Shek-Pvar prefer learning from the work of others, rather than re-inventing the wheel.

For each week that is spent studying or inventing a spell, the Shek-Pvar rolls on the Experience gained through training table in Campaign:2. Spells however are quicker to develop than normal knowledges, so get the following modifiers.

There is a bonus to the study total equal to the current convocation score of the Shek-Pvar. There is a further +1 for every spell in that convocation which is known at a higher level than the spell being learned or invented.

If the study total is higher than the study difficulty, then 1 experience point is gained in the spell. For every five points higher than the study difficulty, an extra point of experience is gained that week.

sect2.title: Grimoires
sect2.para: Initially written to help mavari in their studies, grimoires have become quite common at all levels of skill. They are basically a collection of tracts on a number of different spells. Study of the grimoire will provide knowledge in each of the spells covered.

Like any other book, a grimoire has a level and a quality. When a week is spent studying the grimoire, for each spell which the reader has a lower score in than the level of the grimoire, they get one study gain roll, at the quality of the grimoire. A study roll is possible even if the student has no skill in the spell.

sect3.title: Writing a Grimoire
sect3.para: The author chooses the spells to write about. Any number of spells can be chosen, however they must all be of the same rank, and the same convocation.
The maximum level of the grimoire is equal to the minimum of the lowest score the writer has in any of the spells, and the writer's convocation score minus two per spell beyond the first.
Multi-level spells count as any rank, chosen by the author. Similarly, Common spells count as any convocation.
The quality of the grimoire is worked out as for other books. The time taken is as for a standard book of the same level, multiplied by the number of spells.

sect1.title: The End of Apprenticeship
sect1.para: Beginning Shek-Pvar PCs are assumed to have come to the end of their apprenticeship. They have been released from the bond of apprenticeship and sent into the world as one of the Satia-Mavari (journeyman). They are expected to survive on their wits for at least a year and a day. Any time after that, they may return with a suitable gift for their chantry. Normally, this consists of three items of value, and three 'original-arts', meaning spells the former master does not know how to cast.
Most Satia-Mavari take three to five years to complete this part of their training. After this they may become Shenava (Master) or Viran (Grandmaster).

sect1.title: Pvaric Elementals
sect1.para: Pvarism is restricted to only affected that which is in sight, and even the more powerful magics are restricted in their effects at long range. However, the Shek-Pvar do have a way of affecting that which would otherwise be beyond their reach, and this is through the use of elementals.

Each of the convocations has a type of elemental associated with it. Elementals are sapient spirits formed from the element of their convocation. A common use is to use them as scouts, to spy on places a long way away, or to carry messages between Shek-Pvar. Elementals range greatly in power, and the individual types will be described in the section detailing the relevant convocation. However, a brief guide to them is given here.

sect2.title: Types of Elemental
sect2.para: The strength and capability of an elemental is measured according to its type. A type I elemental is barely sapient, and has little physical strength. Type VIII elementals are amongst the most powerful normally dealt with. They can be quite intelligent, strong willed, and very powerful physically.

Each type of elemental corresponds to a complexity rank for spells. Most spells to control elementals are multi-level, and also common. This means a different spell is needed to summon an elemental of Peleahn instead of a Lyahvi elemental.

sect3.title: Type I Elementals
sect3.para: A type I elemental is the weakest elemental it is possible to summon. It has a base intelligence and will of one, and is incapable of understanding anything but the simplest of commands.
Such an elemental can be ordered to go to a place in line of sight and see if it can see movement, or to carry or fetch an item that can be pointed to.
A type I elemental does not have a long term memory, and cannot remember or understand conversations, or describe things in detail.

sect3.title: Type II Elementals
sect3.para: Type II elementals have an intelligence of one and a will of two. They can follow conditional commands, such as to give warning if something happens, or to follow a person. They can count and recognise things which are not directly related to themselves.
A type II elemental may be given a message, which it will remember (but not understand) and rely to a person. The message cannot be more than a few dozen words.

sect3.title: Type III Elementals
sect3.para: This level of elemental has an intelligence of two, and a will of three. It is capable of acting on its own initiative, and can remember (though not understand) human speech.

It may be given instructions which involve real time interpretation on its part - for example to guard and protect someone, to listen on a conversation and report back, or to hunt down and kill a particular person.

sect3.title: Type IV Elementals
sect3.para: Such elementals have an intelligence of two and a will of four. They will understand commands and act on them much like a human of similar intelligence.
Within the restrictions of the summoning magic, they can be considered to be free willed creatures with a sense of self preservation, reasoning ability and understanding of the world.

sect3.title: Type V Elementals and Above
sect3.para: Elementals of type V or more have an intelligence of three. Their will is equal to their type rank, and they can follow commands as a type IV elemental.

sect2.title: Elemental Bestiary
sect2.para: The following guidelines describe the different types of elementals.

sect3.title: Summoning an Elemental
sect3.para: An elemental is summoned with the use of the Summon Elemental spell. This is a common spell, and one version of it exists for each convocation.

Summoning an elemental takes one minute. The elemental always appears next to the summoner, and a ego check must be made by both the summoner and the elemental as soon as it arrives, in order to see if the elemental is controlled. If control fails, then the elemental will do as it pleases. Roll a d20, on a 1-19, it returns to where it came from. On a 20, it goes on a random rampage, attacking anything in sight.

Assuming the elemental is controlled, then it can be given commands. Very simple commands can be given with gestures, however anything more complicated requires the caster to speak and understand a Pvaric language. This can normally be done with the Speak with Elemental spell.

The elemental must normally remain within range of the spell. If the elemental ever leaves the spell range, then another ego check is required to maintain control of the elemental. On failure, control is lost as when the elemental is first summoned. Success, allows the elemental to be controlled, but a further check is required each minute it remains beyond the normal spell range. An out of range elemental will halt and rest, awaiting further instruction.

sect1.title: Minor Artifacts
sect1.para: Minor artifacts are the most common of the magical items constructed by Shek-Pvar. They are easy and quick to make, though are temporary in nature. They are limited to duplicating the effects of a single convocation.

sect2.title: Creating a Minor Artifact
sect2.para: Firstly, an item must be found which is suitable to contain the powers of a minor artifact. The following suggestions should be used as a guide when determining what material to use.

sect4.title: Fyvria
sect4.para: Wooden or bone staves and wands, or even bags of earth or dried herbs are good. However, the magic does not convey any protection to the focus, so weak materials have a down side.

sect4.title: Jmorvi
sect4.para: Precious metals such as silver and gold, often in the form of wands, amulets or weapons.

sect4.title: Lyahvi
sect4.para: Transparent, reflective or translucent materials are best used for Lyahvi artifacts. Gems and glass is good, as are mirrors, prisms and lenses. Red coloured items also help.

sect4.title: Neutral
sect4.para: Neutrality is everything and nothing. Items are grey, and favour round, smooth objects which represent neutralities central place in the Pvaric wheel.

sect4.title: Odivshe
sect4.para: The colour of Odivshe is blue, so often blue containers of water or ice are used as foci.

sect4.title: Peleahn
sect4.para: Peleahn is orange, and runes and markings on such items are often orange. Combustable materials such as wood, or coal make for good Peleahn artifacts.

sect4.title: Savorya
sect4.para: Representations of knowledge, such as a scroll or book are often used as a focus. Quills are another favourite.

sect3.title: Preparing the Item
sect3.para: The item is prepared with the use of Focus, a multi-level common spell. This purifies the item, giving it a magical aura. This process takes a day.

The rank of the focus used determines the maximum number of charges that can be placed into the item, and is itself affected by how suitable the object itself is. The number of charges per rank of the focus is given by the following chart.

sect3.title: Opening the Item
sect3.para: The item can now, at any point after the item has been prepared, be opened for enchantment. The rank I neutral spell Open is used to do this.

While the item is open, Store (multi-level, neutral) can be used to store spells in the item. Spells are placed into the item in reverse order to what they are going to be cast in. The rank of the spell must be no higher than the rank of the Store spell.

As many spells as the item may contain charges can be cast into the item. Only spells with a casting time of one round can be placed in the item, and all spells must be of the same convocation as the original Focus.

sect3.title: Closing the Enchantment
sect3.para: Once all required spells have been stored, the item should be closed, with Close (I, neutral). At this point the trigger action for the item can be declared - see Close for details.
The minor artifact is now ready for use.

sect2.title: Using Minor Artifacts
sect2.para: A minor artifact can be used by anyone if the trigger event is physical (such as a word or action). If the trigger event is a mental command, then the user must have attuned to the item first, which more or less restricts the item to Shek-Pvar.
When the item is activated, the last spell stored in it is cast at the target designated by the user. If the user has attuned to the item, then they may choose which spell is cast.
The spell goes off on the initiative of the user. For physical trigger events, this is agility x 4. For mental trigger events, this is intelligence x 4.

sect2.title: Decay of Minor Artifacts
sect2.para: Minor artifacts decay with time. Each month (on the new moon), the top spell in any minor artifact decays and is lost. Once all spells have been lost, the item is empty, but will not decay further.
Any minor artifact can be reopened, and new spells stored within it. If the item is left open for long periods, then one spell is lost each day, rather than each month.

sect1.title: Major Artifacts
sect1.para: Major artifacts are more powerful, more flexible and longer lasting than minor artifacts. They are also more complicated to construct, and take much longer to make. Whereas a minor artifact can be constructed in a couple of days, a major artifact can take several months to build.
A major artifact consists of several components - it requires a source of power and a spirit to control it.

sect2.title: Creating the Artifact
sect2.para: The first stage of artifact creation is to purify a suitable item, by use of the Focus spell. This attunes it to the correct convocation. A Grey Mage may create Grey items, which are capable of using all convocations. Other magi however are limited to creating artifacts of only a single convocation. It does not have to be the primary convocation of the magus.

The second stage is to summon and trap a spirit. The False Soul spell does this, crafting an elemental spirit of a particular type. False Soul is always a neutral spell. As for summoning elementals, the rank of the False Soul summons a spirit of equal rank.

When the spirit is summoned, it can be given a purpose. Binding a spirit to a single purpose gives it more power, at the expense of limiting what it will be willing to do. A spirit with a purpose also has more intelligence, so is able to act on its own violation.

sect3.title: Purpose of a Spirit
sect3.para: The normal sort of elementals that get summoned won't do when creating a major artifact. False Soul creates a special sort of spirit. It has a convocation score in its element, which is equal to some multiple of its will. The will of a False Soul is equal to its rank.

The multiplier depends on the purpose which the soul is given. The more restrictive the purpose, the higher the multiplier, but getting the soul to do anything contrary to its purpose, is difficult at best.

sect3.title: Spirits without a Purpose
sect3.para: These spirits are the weakest of all, and have animal level intelligence.

sect3.title: Gaining a Spirit
sect3.para: Spirits are easier to trap and control if they are willing. A willing spirit can be obtained by giving it a purpose. The narrower the purpose, the more powerful the spirit.

Use False Soul to place the spirit into an item. Multi-level neutral spell. The level of the spell gives the will of the spirit that is created. This will is then reduced to put controls on the spirit.
The artifact has a capacity of 10 x will. This is the number of ranks of spells the artifact can store.
The convocation the spirit is attuned to should also be decided.

sect3.title: Energy
sect3.para: The item needs to be powered somehow by an energy source. This can be internal to the spirit, from the owner, or from the outside world. It can also be within the item itself. This is easy, but limited.

sect4.title: Energy Pool
sect4.para: An energy pool is internal to the item. It cannot recharge itself, and needs to be recharged by use of the Recharge spell.
An energy pool has power equal to 5 x its (rank - 1). An item can have as many energy pools as it has room for. A few large energy pools are more efficient than lots of small ones however.
When a spell is cast from the item, it uses a number of points of power equal to its rank.

sect4.title: Energy Font
sect4.para: Never needs recharging, but limited in daily use. Can only have one font in an item. If it has several, the largest is used. Has a daily capacity of 3 x rank of font.

sect4.title: Energy from user
sect4.para: User has to attune themselves to the item. When a spell is used, make a stamina roll of 10 + 5 x rank of spell, or gain one fatigue. If spell matches convocation of both item and user, difficulty reduced by 10.

sect4.title: Energy from the spirit
sect4.para: The energy comes from the spirit.
